query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Ricorditi, lettor, se mai ne l’alpe 2 ti colse nebbia per la qual vedessi 3 non altrimenti che per pelle talpe,
4 come, quando i vapori umidi e spessi 5 a diradar cominciansi, la spera 6 del sol debilemente entra per essi;
7 e fia la tua imagine leggera 8 in giugnere a veder com’ io rividi 9 lo sole in pria, che già nel corcar era.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Remember, reader, if ever in the Alps 2 a fog caught you through which you saw 3 no otherwise than through the skin of moles,
4 how, when the humid and dense vapors 5 begin to thin out, the sphere 6 of the sun enters through them feebly;
7 and your light imagination 8 will suffice to see how I saw again 9 the sun before it was already sunset.
**Cornish:**
1 Koweth, leveror, mar nagas yn Alpen 2 an nebel a'th kymmeras, dre henna 3 ny weles ef mar nagas dre'n croen talp,
4 kepar, pan an vaporyow tomm ha tewl 5 a leverel dhe dardha, an sper 6 a'n howl a leverel drethon gwan.
7 Ha fyth dha ymajyn efan 8 dhe dhaskav dhe weles kepar vy 9 a welas an howl kyns o ev yn korcar.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Sì, pareggiando i miei co’ passi fidi 11 del mio maestro, usci’ fuor di tal nube 12 ai raggi morti già ne’ bassi lidi.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Yes, matching my steps with the faithful 11 steps of my master, I emerged from such a cloud 12 to the rays already dead on the low shores.
**Cornish:**
10 Ia, ow parya ow passyow gans an fydh 11 a'm mester, vy a dheuthas for a henna nebel 12 dhe'n rajyow marow ow lemmyn yn an isel lydyow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 O imaginativa che ne rube 14 talvolta sì di fuor, ch’om non s’accorge 15 perché dintorno suonin mille tube,
16 chi move te, se ’l senso non ti porge? 17 Moveti lume che nel ciel s’informa, 18 per sé o per voler che giù lo scorge.
query.result:
**English:**
13 O imagination, that sometimes 14 so steals you away from outside, that one does not notice 15 why a thousand trumpets sound all around,
16 what moves you, if the senses do not offer it to you? 17 A light moves you that takes shape in heaven, 18 by itself or by a will that sends it down.
**Cornish:**
13 O ymajynasyon, pyth a'th rub 14 a-veythyn kemmys a-ves, na'th gorra 15 fatel pan myll tube a leverel owtro,
16 pyth a'th mova, mar ny lever an sens dhys? 17 Lome a'th mova, pyth a leveris furvys yn an nef, 18 rag rag erel wolons pyth a'th gorra dhe'n bewnans.

**English:**
19 From her wickedness that changed form 20 into the bird that takes most delight in singing, 21 the mark appeared in my imagination;
22 and here my mind was so constricted 23 within itself that nothing from outside 24 was received by it at that time.
**Cornish:**
19 A-dhyworth ympynnyeth ow toskas furv, 20 yn onan a gar ow kanas moyha, 21 yma'm ymajansi ow toskas ow tos.
22 Hag ama yma'm powes o wrug kemeres, 23 bys vy dhe bys, na veu nevra dhe ves, 24 neb tra a veu resyvys gansof.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 E come questa imagine rompeo 32 sé per sé stessa, a guisa d’una bulla 33 cui manca l’acqua sotto qual si feo,
34 surse in mia visïone una fanciulla 35 piangendo forte, e dicea: «O regina, 36 perché per ira hai voluto esser nulla?
37 Ancisa t’hai per non perder Lavina; 38 or m’hai perduta! Io son essa che lutto, 39 madre, a la tua pria ch’a l’altrui ruina».
query.result:
**English:**
31 And as this image broke 32 of its own accord, like a bubble 33 that bursts when the water beneath it fails,
34 there arose in my vision a young woman 35 weeping bitterly, and she said: “O queen, 36 why in your anger have you wished to be nothing?
37 You have killed yourself so as not to lose Lavinia; 38 now you have lost me! I am the one who grieves, 39 mother, for your ruin before anyone else’s”.
**Cornish:**
31 Ha della bys ymajansi hemma a dorras, 32 a-dro dhe bys honan, kepar bul, 33 pan vynnow an dowr a-woles,
34 y'm welas ow toskas onan yowynk, 35 ow gena gans kreffa, ha ow leverel: 36 “O reyn, dre henna dhe dhe wroth,
37 ow tisheth dhe dhe honan dhe vyns Lavina; 38 mes ow tisheth vy! My a'n onan ow gena, 39 mam, rag dhe dhe ruina dhe dhe honan, rag dhe dhe ruina a neb aral”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Ma come al sol che nostra vista grava 53 e per soverchio sua figura vela, 54 così la mia virtù quivi mancava.
query.result:
**English:**
52 But just as the sun, which weighs upon our sight, 53 and with its excessive brightness veils its form, 54 so my strength failed me there.
**Cornish:**
52 Mes kepar ha’n howl, a bowys orth y’n golwg, 53 ha dre worhemmyn ughel a wra’n golwg orth y’n furv, 54 hemma oen yma vy nerth a veu kowl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 «Questo è divino spirito, che ne la 56 via da ir sù ne drizza sanza prego, 57 e col suo lume sé medesmo cela.
query.result:
**English:**
55 "This is a divine spirit, who on 56 the upward way directs us without asking, 57 and with his light conceals himself.
**Cornish:**
55 “Hemma yw spyrys dowr, neb yn 56 an fordh dhe’n ughel a’n gwreugh dhe’n-dre heb gows, 57 ha gans golwg y honan a wra’n kuchemys.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Sì fa con noi, come l’uom si fa sego; 59 ché quale aspetta prego e l’uopo vede, 60 malignamente già si mette al nego.
query.result:
**English:**
58 He acts towards us as a man does who is silent, 59 for he who waits for a request and sees the need, 60 wickedly sets himself to deny it.
**Cornish:**
58 Ev a wra gans kepar ha’n den a wra mudh, 59 rag neb a wra gorthyp pregoth ha gweles an keus, 60 yn dorgrys a wra’n omsettya dhe’n nagha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Or accordiamo a tanto invito il piede; 62 procacciam di salir pria che s’abbui, 63 ché poi non si poria, se ’l dì non riede».
query.result:
**English:**
61 Now let us attune our steps to such an invitation; 62 let us strive to ascend before it grows dark, 63 for then it would not be possible, unless the day returns.
**Cornish:**
61 Nyns, demedhons y’n treys dhe’n galwadh ma, 62 ha prosyons dhe dhyski kyns na wra tewl, 63 rag ny wra possybyl wosa, mar ny wra’n an jydh ow trehedhes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Così disse il mio duca, e io con lui 65 volgemmo i nostri passi ad una scala; 66 e tosto ch’io al primo grado fui,
67 senti’mi presso quasi un muover d’ala 68 e ventarmi nel viso e dir: ‘Beati 69 pacifici, che son sanz’ ira mala!’.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Thus spoke my guide, and I with him 65 turned our steps to a staircase; 66 and as soon as I was on the first step,
67 I felt near me almost a movement of wings 68 and a wind blowing in my face and saying: ‘Blessed 69 are the peacemakers, who are without evil wrath!’.
**Cornish:**
64 Marow a leveris ow th’aga, ha my a-gena 65 ow troas ow passow dhe’n ewn scar; 66 ha marow bys vyth o’n kynsa gradh,
67 y’m tevis ow klevys marow ow movyans a-dhe’n esel 68 ha gwyns ow tevi ow fas ha leverel: ‘Benygys 69 an pesadowryon, neb a-dhe’n kas mala!’

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Già eran sovra noi tanto levati 71 li ultimi raggi che la notte segue, 72 che le stelle apparivan da più lati.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Already the last rays that night follows 71 were rising so high above us, 72 that the stars were appearing from many sides.
**Cornish:**
70 Yn-dann o’n ughella o’n ughella 71 an diwettha gwawlow a sew an nos, 72 ow steren a-dhallethys owth usi a-leow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 ‘O virtù mia, perché sì ti dilegue?’, 74 fra me stesso dicea, ché mi sentiva 75 la possa de le gambe posta in triegue.
query.result:
**English:**
73 ‘O my strength, why do you desert me so?’, 74 I said to myself, for I felt 75 the power of my legs put to a truce.
**Cornish:**
73 ‘O’m nerth, peraga’th owth a-dhalleth marow marow?’, 74 a leveris dhe’n ow honan, rag ow tevis 75 an gallos a’m eskern posys yn triegue.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Noi eravam dove più non saliva 77 la scala sù, ed eravamo affissi, 78 pur come nave ch’a la piaggia arriva.
query.result:
**English:**
76 We were where the staircase no longer climbed 77 upwards, and we were fixed, 78 just like a ship that arrives at the shore.
**Cornish:**
76 Ni o’n ughella o’n le may fetha 77 an scar dhe’n ughella, ha ni o’n festys, 78 marow marow long avel a dheuth dhe’n fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 E io attesi un poco, s’io udissi 80 alcuna cosa nel novo girone; 81 poi mi volsi al maestro mio, e dissi:
82 «Dolce mio padre, dì, quale offensione 83 si purga qui nel giro dove semo? 84 Se i piè si stanno, non stea tuo sermone».
query.result:
**English:**
79 And I waited a little, to see if I could hear 80 anything in the new circle; 81 then I turned to my master and said:
82 “My sweet father, tell me, what offense 83 is purged here in the circle where we are? 84 If our feet are still, let not your speech be still.”
**Cornish:**
79 Ha my a-welas ow bys vyth, rag ow klevyas 80 neppyth yn an now gylgh; 81 ena a droas dhe’n ow mester, ha leveris:
82 “Ow hara tas, lever, pyth offans 83 a-berthir yma yn an gylgh le mayns? 84 Marow an tres a-dhalleth, na dhalleth ow sermon.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Ed elli a me: «L’amor del bene, scemo 86 del suo dover, quiritta si ristora; 87 qui si ribatte il mal tardato remo.
query.result:
**English:**
85 And he to me: “The love of good, bereft 86 of its duty, is restored here; 87 here the oar that was delayed is beaten again.
**Cornish:**
85 Ha henna dhe’n ow: “Karanteth an da, skem 86 a’y dlever, yma a-berthir; 87 yma a-berthir an rem a-dheuth dhe’n ughella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Ma perché più aperto intendi ancora, 89 volgi la mente a me, e prenderai 90 alcun buon frutto di nostra dimora».
query.result:
**English:**
88 But so that you may understand even more clearly, 89 turn your mind to me, and you will gather 90 some good fruit from our conversation.
**Cornish:**
88 Mes rag ow komprehendya moy es, 89 tro dha bowes dhe’n ow, ha ty a-gemmer 90 neppyth da bara da ow conversyans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 «Né creator né creatura mai», 92 cominciò el, «figliuol, fu sanza amore, 93 o naturale o d’animo; e tu ’l sai.
query.result:
**English:**
91 “Neither creator nor creature ever”, 92 he began, “my son, was without love, 93 either natural or of the soul; and you know it.
**Cornish:**
91 “Nag creator nag creatur byth”, 92 a leveris henna, “ow mab, o’n fetha heb karanteth, 93 po naturel po a’n eneval; ha ty a-wodh henna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Lo naturale è sempre sanza errore, 95 ma l’altro puote errar per malo obietto 96 o per troppo o per poco di vigore.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Natural love is always without error, 95 but the other can err because of a bad object 96 or because of too much or too little vigor.
**Cornish:**
94 An karanteth naturel yw byth heb kamm, 95 mes an aral a-all gasa kamm dre objekt drog 96 po dre re beis po re byghan a nerth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Quinci comprender puoi ch’esser convene 104 amor sementa in voi d’ogne virtute 105 e d’ogne operazion che merta pene.
query.result:
**English:**
103 From this you can understand that love must be 104 the seed in you of every virtue 105 and of every action that deserves reward.
**Cornish:**
103 A-dhia ytho komprehendra hy bos dhe vos, 104 kar an garow yw had ynwi dhe vos a-ugh oll virtus, 105 ha dhe oll oberasyon a-ugh merita poen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Resta, se dividendo bene stimo, 113 che ’l mal che s’ama è del prossimo; ed esso 114 amor nasce in tre modi in vostro limo.
query.result:
**English:**
112 It remains, if I judge correctly by dividing well, 113 that the evil that is loved is of one's neighbor; and this 114 love is born in three ways in your clay.
**Cornish:**
112 Yma, mar kewsys vy dhevidedh da, 113 an drok a garir yw a'n nessa; ha henna 114 karanteth a dhevedh yn tri fordh yn aga korf.

**English:**
115 There is he who, in order for his neighbor to be brought low, 116 hopes for excellence, and desires only for this 117 that he be placed low in his greatness;
118 there is he who fears to lose power, favor, honor, and fame 119 because others surpass him, 120 so that he is so saddened that he loves the opposite;
121 and there is he who seems to be shamed by an injury, 122 so that he becomes greedy for revenge, 123 and such a one must desire the evil of others.
**Cornish:**
115 Yma neb, rag tas gorra y nessa omdhiskwedhys, 116 a spyr excellens, ha ragath henna hep 117 a gar y vos ow gorra yn y veurder.
118 Yma neb a omdhiskwedh colli, gras, onor ha klodh 119 rag owen a golli rag neb aral a'n drehedh, 120 ow henna a wra dhesempys marow bys vyth.
121 Ha neb aral a wra dhesempys marow rag omdhiskwedh, 122 marow bys vyth a wra dhesempys marow rag venjans, 123 ha marow henna a wra dhesempys marow rag drok aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Questo triforme amor qua giù di sotto 125 si piange: or vo’ che tu de l’altro intende, 126 che corre al ben con ordine corrotto.
query.result:
**English:**
124 This threefold love is lamented down here below: 125 now I want you to understand about the other, 126 which runs to the good with a corrupt order.
**Cornish:**
124 An trifordh karanteth ma a-is 125 yw bewys: mes nyns a vyn agan komprehendya 126 a'n aral, a red dhe'n da yn fordh omdhiskwedhys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ciascun confusamente un bene apprende 128 nel qual si queti l’animo, e disira; 129 per che di giugner lui ciascun contende.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Each one confusedly apprehends a good 128 in which the soul finds peace and desires; 129 for which reason each one strives to reach it.
**Cornish:**
127 Pep onan yn omdhiskwedhys a dhevedh da 128 da yn fordh omdhiskwedhys yn aga eneval 129 rag henna a wra dhesempys marow rag aga gavas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Se lento amore a lui veder vi tira 131 o a lui acquistar, questa cornice, 132 dopo giusto penter, ve ne martira.
query.result:
**English:**
130 If slow love draws you to see him 131 or to acquire him, this cornice, 132 after just repentance, will torment you for it.
**Cornish:**
130 Mar karanteth omdhiskwedhys a wra dhesempys marow rag y weles 131 po dhesempys marow rag y gavas, an cornys ma 132 wosa penedhans just, a wra dhesempys marow rag henna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Altro ben è che non fa l’uom felice; 134 non è felicità, non è la buona 135 essenza, d’ogne ben frutto e radice.
query.result:
**English:**
133 There is another good that makes man happy; 134 it is not happiness, it is not the good 135 essence, the fruit and root of every good.
**Cornish:**
133 Yma da yw da yw gwella nag wra den vyth lowen; 134 nyns yw lowender, nyns yw an da 135 essens, frooth ha gwreydh a-ugh oll an da.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 L’amor ch’ad esso troppo s’abbandona, 137 di sovr’ a noi si piange per tre cerchi; 138 ma come tripartito si ragiona,
139 tacciolo, acciò che tu per te ne cerchi».
query.result:
**English:**
136 Love that abandons itself too much to it 137 is lamented above us for three circles; 138 but since it is reasoned about in three parts,
139 I am silent about it, so that you may search for it for yourself».
**Cornish:**
136 An karanteth a wra dhesempys marow rag henna re beu 137 yw bewys a-ugh onan rag tri cyrch; 138 mes rag henna yw resonsys a-dro dhe'n tri fordh,
139 vyth a wra dhesempys marow a-dro dhe'n henna, marow bys vyth a wra dhesempys marow rag y hwilas rag agan honan».
